content.description: Sit start from the large notch, then work up the large sidepulls and some flat crimps to make a big move to the arete.
content.location: It is the left/easternmost problem on the boulder.

content.description: Sit start from extended sidepulls. This might be tougher if you can't span it. Work up a couple good ledges.
content.location: It is in the center of the boulder.

content.description: Sit start with good low feet and two good hand holds on the blunt arete, and sort of a squat or full sit start depending on your height. Work along the arete (flat spot behind is out) stepping up on some decent feet on the face for the big reach to the top of the block on the right. There are good holds to top out.
content.location: It is the furthest left climb on the Courtside Boulder.

content.description: Stand starting with dueling pinches and your feet out to the right on a downward-sloping edge. Move your left hand up to a small, left, vertical crimp, and your right follows up the starting pinch to an ever thining, undercling crack. Get a foot up to a crappy foot below the starting right pinch before getting a wonderful block to the far right before the big (or dynamic if you're a little shorter) move to the very smooth and not-so-great, deep crack at the top. There's a V3 sequence somewhere in here without using that far right block. I am still trying to unlock that - so if you do, put it up here!
content.location: The right pinch is the most obvious feature, and look for the freshly cleaned, top right, leaning, finishing crack at the tippy top.

content.description: Sit start with your feet to the left on a solid block, your left hand in the best part of the start of the crack, and your right hand on a solid rail. Pull yourself up for a quick slap to the block to the right, adjust your feet, and go for the left block with feet on the starting right rail. The topout is the crux with less-than-optimal sloper and 2/3 finger crimp.
content.location: Look for the sloppy old school Window's logo that make up the 4 main blocks of this section of the boulder. The solid right rail is one of the obvious features.

content.description: Sit start with your left hand in the best part of the thin finger crack, your right palm pressing down on the low block, and your feet on the lichen ridden face. Pull yourself vertical, continue to work the same crack as it widens to a full hand, and layback to the top with a potential sloper for your left if you need it.
content.location: As the boulder bends in, this is the start of the old Windows logo cracks.

content.description: Courtside  is a short boulder that's good for solo if the main cliff feels a bit too sketchy for you without a spotter. There is an easy walkoff.
